1.0	INTRODUCTION
This Risk Management Plan/Process Safety Management Manual (RMP/PSM Manual) has been prepared for Nelson Brothers, LLC in accordance with the EPA regulations 40 CFR 68, Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions and OSHA regulations 29 CFR 1910.119, "Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals". The purpose of this RMP/PSM Manual is to assist with the prevention of accidental releases of toxic and flammable substances that can cause harm to the public, facility employees, and to the environment.

1.1	Operations
Nelson Brothers, LLC is located at 500 Old Baltimore Road in Parrish, Alabama. The site consists of 12 reactors and 60+ bulk storage tanks of raw materials and finished products.  The facility operates on a 24-hour, 7 day per week schedule. The anhydrous ammonia storage facility at the plant consists of a 10,000-gallon storage tank located on a concrete pad adjacent to the R-800 tank farm. Vapor and liquid connections are provided for receiving bulk ammonia deliveries by tank truck.  The deliveries are made by Tanner Industries.

1.2	Applicability
Anhydrous ammonia is stored on site as a pressurized liquid in a 10,000-gallon aboveground storage tank (TK80543). The presence of approximately 52,000 pounds (i.e., greater than 10,000 pounds) of anhydrous ammonia requires compliance with EPAs RMP rules (Risk Management Program, 40 CFR 68) and OSHAs PSM rules (Process Safety Management, 29 CFR 1910.119). The facility is subject to RMP Program 3 requirements as specified in 40 CFR 68.10 based on the determination that the toxic endpoint for a worst-case release of anhydrous ammonia is within the vicinity of public receptors. The facility submitted the initial Risk Management Plan to the EPA on January 31, 2020. Nelson Brothers will fully update and re-submit the RMP at least once every five years.  

2.0	PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION
Nelson Brothers, LLC maintains current safety information regarding the storage, use and off-loading of anh

ydrous ammonia in accordance with 40 CFR 68.65. Safety information is presented in the following sections.

2.1	Hazards of Regulated Substance
The following information has been compiled to identify the hazards of anhydrous ammonia:
	SDS (Anhydrous Ammonia)
	A Basic Understanding of Anhydrous Ammonia - developed by Airgas Inc.

2.2	Maximum Intended Inventory
The maximum intended inventory of anhydrous ammonia is 43,775 lbs. based on the following:
	Tank TK80543 is a 10,000-gallon storage tank.
	The maximum fill setting is 85% (per SOP: DM-200-1). The contents of TK80543 are limited by administrative controls to 8,500 gallons of liquid.
	At 5.15 lb./gal for anhydrous ammonia at 60 °F and 92.9 psi, the maximum liquid content of TK80543 is 43,775 pounds.

2.3	Safe Upper and Lower Limits
The following information was provided to Nelson Brothers, LLC for the safe upper and lower limits for the system: 
	Tank TK80543: 265 psig @ 150 ?F; 10,000-gallon gross
	The system contains a vaporizer, air mixer, air heater, and other components typically associated with the storage and use of anhydrous ammonia. 

2.4	Consequences of Deviation 
The consequences of deviation could potentially result in releases to the environment or exposure of anhydrous ammonia to employees or to the public.
When anhydrous ammonia is cooled or compressed, it is in the liquid form. Storing it under pressure prevents it from vaporizing and makes it available for use in large volumes. One cubic foot of anhydrous ammonia in a liquid state produces 855 cubic feet of ammonia gas
When anhydrous ammonia is released from compression in a storage tank (200 psi) to the atmosphere (0 psi), the temperature drops from 100 ?F to minus 28 ?F. At this temperature, ammonia will freeze/burn human skin on contact and clothing can be frozen to the skin. Since anhydrous ammonia is stored under high pressure, a sudden rupture can shoot ammonia 10 to 20 feet from the point of release.

2.5	Materials of Construction
Th

e following materials were used in the construction of the ammonia tank and supply lines:
	Tank shell 	SA-212-B-FO
	Pipe	Stainless Steel 316L
	Bolts	SA-193-B7
	Nuts	SA-194-2H
	Gaskets	Garlock Nylon
Note: Ammonia is corrosive to brass, copper and galvanized components and fittings. When these components and fittings come in contact with ammonia liquid or vapor, the metal will corrode and will fail. 

2.6	Relief System Design & Design Basis 
Relief valves, located on the top of the ammonia storage tanks, were designed in accordance with the following guidelines:
	American National Standard Institute (ANSI) K61.1 - Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia
	OSHA 29 CFR 1910.111 Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia.

2.7	Ventilation System Design 
A ventilation system has not been designed for the Ammonia system since none of the process is located in an enclosed area.

2.8	Design Codes and Standards Employed
The following design codes and standards were employed in the construction of the Ammonia system:
	American National Standard Institute (ANSI) K61.1 - Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia (1999 Edition)
	OSHA 29 CFR 1910.111 Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia

2.9	Safety Systems
Guidelines from the 1999 edition of ANSI K61.1, Safety Requirements for the Storage and handling of Anhydrous Ammonia were reviewed regarding the use of water on ammonia spills. It was determined that a deluge system should not be used during a significant spill. 

3.0	PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS 
The most recent Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was completed on January 9, 2025, with a review team of personnel from Nelson Brothers, LLC. In accordance with 40 CFR 68.67, the process hazard analysis addressed the following:
	The hazards of the process
	The findings from all incident investigations required under 40 CFR 68.81, as well as any other potential failure scenarios
	Engineering and administrative controls ap

plicable to the hazards and their interrelationships such as appropriate application of detection methodologies to provide early warning of releases. (Acceptable detection methods might include process monitoring and control instrumentation with alarms, and detection hardware such as hydrocarbon sensors.)
	Consequences of failure of engineering and administrative controls
	Stationary source siting
	Human factors
	A qualitative evaluation of a range of the possible safety and health effects of failure of controls
	Natural hazards that could cause or exacerbate an accidental release
	Any gaps in safety between the codes, standards, or practices to which the process was designed and constructed and the most current version of applicable codes, standards, or practices.

4.0	FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
During the past 5 years, the Nelson Brothers facility has experienced no accidental releases from the ammonia process that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. If an accidental release of ammonia should occur, the facility will document all the necessary information pursuant to the requirements of § 68.42 (b).

5.0	OPERATING PROCEDURES 
Operating procedures are readily accessible to employees who operate or maintain the ASA system. The following procedures have been developed:
	Liquid Ammonia Tank Truck Off-loading Checklist
	R-800 Reactor Cleaning Procedure
	ASA Standard Operating Procedure

The operating procedures will be reviewed by Nelson Brothers, LLC as often as necessary to ensure they reflect current operating practice, including changes that result from changes in process chemicals, technology, and equipment, and changes to stationary sources. Nelson Brothers, LLC will certify annually that these operating procedures are current and accurate.

Nelson Brothers, LLC has developed and implemented safe work practices

to provide for the control of hazards during operations such as lockout/tagout; confined space entry; opening process equipment or piping; and control over entrance into the ASA process by maintenance, contractor, laboratory, or other support personnel. These safe work practices are applicable to employees and contractors.

6.0	TRAINING
6.1	Initial Training
Each employee presently involved in operating the ASA system, and each employee before being involved in operating a newly assigned process, shall be trained in an overview of the process and in the operating procedures. The training will include emphasis on the specific safety and health hazards, emergency operations including shutdown, and safe work practices applicable to the employee's job tasks. Additional training will be provided to Nelson Brothers, LLC personnel by Tanner Industries, Inc.

6.2	Refresher Training
Refresher training shall be provided at least every 3 years, and more often, if necessary, to each employee involved in operations involving ammonia to ensure that employees understand and adhere to the operating procedures. The content of the refresher training will be similar to the information provided during initial training.

7.0	MECHANICAL INTEGRITY
Nelson Brothers, LLC maintains the ongoing integrity of the ASA system by completing maintenance activities as specified in documents provided by the manufacturer of the process components. Specifically, the following manufacturer's maintenance programs are used on specific components of the ASA system:

	The tank and piping should be visually inspected at least every three months.
	Valve stems should be protected and occasionally lubricated with a light coating of grease or petroleum jelly.
	Safety relief valves are provided with caps to keep out rain, snow, dirt, etc. 
	Safety relief valves are stamped with a 5-year expiration date. These valves will be replaced prior to their date of expiration.
	Hose connections must have protective caps

.

The mechanical integrity program includes the inspection and testing of pressure vessels, emergency shutdown controls, pumps, and other equipment associated with operating the system.

Inspection and testing procedures have been developed by Nelson Brothers, LLC that follow accepted good engineering practices. The frequency of inspections and tests of process equipment will be consistent with applicable manufacturers recommendations, industry standards or codes, good engineering practices and prior operating experience.

Employees responsible for the on-going integrity of process equipment on the ASA system will be trained in an overview of the process. Training will include a review of the hazards associated with anhydrous ammonia as well as operating procedures associated with maintaining the equipments integrity.

Nelson Brothers, LLC has developed a checklist to document each inspection and test that is required to be completed on the system. The checklist identifies the following information:

	date of the inspection or test
	the name of the person who performed the inspection or test
	the serial number or other identifier of the equipment on which the inspection or test was performed
	a description of the inspection or test performed
	the results of the inspection or test

When deficiencies are identified during inspections, Nelson Brothers, LLC will correct the problem and return the ASA system to acceptable parameter limits specified in the process safety information. Corrections will occur A) before further use, or B) in a safe and timely manner when necessary means are taken to ensure safe operation.

8.0	MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE
Nelson Brothers, LLC has established and implemented written procedures to manage changes to the ASA system equipment and associated procedures. These procedures ensure that the following considerations are addressed prior to any change:

	The technical basis for the proposed change
	Impact of change on safety and health


Modifications to operating procedures
	Necessary time period for the change
	Authorization requirements for the proposed change

The ASA system equipment and associated procedures will be reviewed annually to ensure that documentation included in this manual reflects current personnel and actual operating conditions.

Nelson Brothers, LLC employees and contractors involved in performing maintenance on the ASA system will be informed of, and trained in, the change prior to start-up of the process or affected part of the process.

If a change covered by this section results in a change in the process safety information, such information shall be updated accordingly. If a change described above results in a change in the operating procedures or practices required by 40 CFR 68.69 (Operating Procedures), such procedures or practices shall be updated accordingly.

9.0	PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEW (PSSR) 
A pre-startup safety review was completed by Nelson Brothers, LLC on the ASA process prior to initial startup. Additional PSSRs will be completed when a modification is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information. The pre-start-up safety review will confirm the following information prior to the introduction of anhydrous ammonia to the process:

	Construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications
	Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate
	Modified stationary sources meet the requirements contained in Management of Change 
	Training of each employee involved in operating the process has been completed.
	Operating procedures have been developed for initial startup and startup following an emergency shutdown.

10.0	COMPLIANCE AUDITS
In accordance with 40 CFR 68.79, Nelson Brothers, LLC will evaluate compliance with the provisions of the RMP/PSM Plan at least once every 3 years to verify that the procedures and practices are adequate and being followed. The audits findings wi

ll be documented. Written reports of the findings and corresponding corrective actions taken will be maintained for five years. The most recent Compliance Audit was conducted by Clint Fritz on January 21, 2023. 

11.0	INCIDENT INVESTIGATION
Nelson Brothers, LLC will investigate each incident which resulted in, or could have reasonably resulted in, a catastrophic release, in accordance with 40 CFR 68.81. An incident investigation will be initiated as soon as possible, but not later than 24 hours after the incident occurred. Nelson Brothers, LLC will promptly address and resolve the investigation findings and recommendations, and resolutions and corrective actions will be documented and maintained for five years.

An HSE Incident Report is used by Nelson Brothers, LLC to document, address, and resolve the findings of the investigation. The report includes the following information:
	Date of incident
	Date investigation began
	A description of the incident
	The factors that contributed to the incident
	Any recommendations resulting from the investigation.

The HSE Incident Report also includes fields for documenting resolutions and corrective actions. Upon completion, the report will be reviewed with all affected employees and contractors whose job tasks are relevant to the incident findings.
 
12.0	EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION 
Nelson Brothers, LLC will consult with employees involved with ASA manufacturing regarding the development of PHAs and other elements of the RMP and PSM programs. Employees will be consulted to address and resolve the findings of PHAs, compliance audits, and incident investigations. 

The RMP Plan is readily available to all Nelson Brothers employees and a written notice will be issued annually so personnel will know how and where the Plan can be accessed.
Employees knowledgeable in the ASA manufacturing process have the authority to recommend that the process be shut down based on the potential for a catastrophic ammonia release. Qualified oper

ators have the authority to shut down the ASA manufacturing process based on the potential for a catastrophic release.

Employees can report to management and/or the EPA any unaddressed hazards that could lead to a catastrophic release, accident, or other noncompliance associated with the RMP Program. Employees can choose to report unaddressed issues anonymously. A record of these reports will be maintained for three years.

13.0	EMERGENCY RESPONSE
13.1	Non-Responding Facility
The Nelson Brothers, LLC Specialty Chemicals Facility is designated as a Non-Responding Facility which means employees will not respond to accidental releases, and instead, the facility will rely on local public responders from Walker County and the City of Parrish to respond to an accidental release of ammonia. According to OSHA, Emergency Response is defined as a response effort by employees from outside the immediate release area.to an occurrence which could result, or is likely to result, in an uncontrolled release of ammonia. Excluded from this definition is the quick response to an incidental release of ammonia where it can be controlled at the time of the release by an employee in the immediate release area, or by maintenance personnel, where there is no potential safety or health hazard.  Due to the nature of anhydrous ammonia, only the most minor incidents would be included in this exception due to the immediacy of the dispersion of the ammonia plume and the threat to people on and off site.

13.2 	Emergency Action Plan (EAP)
Nelson Brothers, LLC has prepared an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) in accordance with the OSHA regulations found at 29 CFR 1910.38(a). The EAP communicates to employees the policies and procedures to follow in the event of an emergency. The EAP also provides the details of when and how to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response, including providing timely data and information detailing the current understanding and best estimates of t

he nature of the accidental release. 

13.3		Notification Exercises 
At least once each calendar year, Nelson Brothers will conduct an exercise of the emergency response notification system. During a notification exercise, the Walker County LEPC, the Parrish Fire Department, and the Emergency Response Contractor will be contacted to ensure that, in the event of an accidental release, the contact information is accurate. A record of the notification exercise will be maintained for 5 years.

13.4	Emergency Response Coordination 
At least annually, Nelson Brothers will coordinate response needs with the Walker County LEPC and the Parrish Fire Department to ensure the site is addressed in the community emergency response plan and to ensure these agencies are aware of the quantity of ammonia stored on site and the risks presented. Nelson Brothers will provide the Walker County LEPC and the Parrish Fire Department with the most recent EAP, emergency contact information, and any other information necessary for developing and implementing an effective community emergency response plan. The purpose of the annual coordination is to allow the facility to update and discuss the information being provided and to allow the local authorities to provide any updated information on the community emergency response plan. The coordination will be documented and include contact information (name, phone number, email address), dates and description of the coordination activities.
